items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Llanymynech river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible Monday overnight.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Predicted peaks:-  Llanymynech 3.7m to 4.0m Monday overnight.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services and or Local Authorities.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  by 10am on 16/09/25, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising in response to recent heavy rainfall. Flooding is possible this morning and through to this afternoon, Monday 15/09/2025. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Ure, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around The River Ure and tributaries, from its source downstream to Kilgram. Rainfall is expected throughout the day and into this evening. We are closely monitoring the situation and do not expect to issue any flood warnings at this time. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourse and do not attempt to walk, drive or cycle through flood water. Take care and consider activating your flood plan if you have one. This message will be updated by 21:00 on Monday 15/09/2025, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Sandyford Brook, Ridings Brook, Saredon Brook

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
We continue to monitor the situation. Our incident response staff are actively monitoring river levels and the weather forecast.
Please avoid contact with flood water.

Heavy rainfall in the early hours of this morning has caused rising river levels which may lead to flooding of land and road. Flooding is possible from 10:00 AM today 15/09/2025.

Areas most at risk include Rivers Esk and Irthing and other watercourses, including low lying areas around Longtown and Brampton.

Persistent rainfall is expected to continue throughout the day today into the evening.

Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 16/09/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around The Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water.
Further flooding is possible this afternoon as river levels are rising due to rainfall.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 15/09/2025, or as the situation changes.

Heavy rainfall in the early hours of this morning has caused rising river levels which may lead to flooding of land and road. Flooding is possible from 9:00 AM today 15/09/2025.

Areas most at risk include Rivers Wampool and Ellen and other watercourses, from Dalston to Maryport including low lying areas around Wigton, Abbeytown, Silloth, Allonby, Aspatria and Dearham.
 
Persistent rainfall is expected to continue throughout the day today into the evening.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.

This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 16/09/2025, or as the situation changes.
